<p>Compared with the decommunization efforts of the other former constituents of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, decommunization in Russia has been restricted to half-measures, if conducted at all.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTERyavec200313&#95;362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyavec200313-362"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Notable anti-communist measures in the Russian Federation include the banning of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Communist Party of the Soviet Union</a> (and the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Communist Party of the Russian Federation">Communist Party of the Russian Federation</a>) as well as changing the names of some Russian cities back to what they were before the 1917 <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a> (Leningrad to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>, Sverdlovsk to <a href="/wiki/Yekaterinburg" title="Yekaterinburg">Yekaterinburg</a> and Gorky to <a href="/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod" title="Nizhny Novgorod">Nizhny Novgorod</a>),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEShevchenko2015&#95;363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShevchenko2015-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> though others were maintained, with <a href="/wiki/Ulyanovsk" title="Ulyanovsk">Ulyanovsk</a> (former Simbirsk), <a href="/wiki/Tolyatti" title="Tolyatti">Tolyatti</a> (former Stavropol) and <a href="/wiki/Kirov,_Kirov_Oblast" title="Kirov, Kirov Oblast">Kirov</a> (former Vyatka) being examples. Even though Leningrad and Sverdlovsk were renamed, regions that were named after them are still officially called Leningrad and Sverdlovsk oblasts.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Spasskaya_Tower,_photographed_in_1883,_published_1884_(Saviour_Tower_-_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F),_Moscow_Kremlin,_Red_Square.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/The_Spasskaya_Tower%2C_photographed_in_1883%2C_published_1884_%28Saviour_Tower_-_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F%29%2C_Moscow_Kremlin%2C_Red_Square.jpg/250px-The_Spasskaya_Tower%2C_photographed_in_1883%2C_published_1884_%28Saviour_Tower_-_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F%29%2C_Moscow_Kremlin%2C_Red_Square.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="235" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/The_Spasskaya_Tower%2C_photographed_in_1883%2C_published_1884_%28Saviour_Tower_-_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F%29%2C_Moscow_Kremlin%2C_Red_Square.jpg/330px-The_Spasskaya_Tower%2C_photographed_in_1883%2C_published_1884_%28Saviour_Tower_-_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F%29%2C_Moscow_Kremlin%2C_Red_Square.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/The_Spasskaya_Tower%2C_photographed_in_1883%2C_published_1884_%28Saviour_Tower_-_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F%29%2C_Moscow_Kremlin%2C_Red_Square.jpg/500px-The_Spasskaya_Tower%2C_photographed_in_1883%2C_published_1884_%28Saviour_Tower_-_%D0%A1%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F%29%2C_Moscow_Kremlin%2C_Red_Square.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1498" data-file-height="1852" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Spasskaya_Tower" title="Spasskaya Tower">Spasskaya Tower</a> had kept its red star and did not restore the two-headed eagle present before communist takeover.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Nostalgia_for_the_Soviet_Union" title="Nostalgia for the Soviet Union">Nostalgia for the Soviet Union</a> is gradually on the rise in Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTERosenberg2016&#95;365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERosenberg2016-365"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Communist symbols continue to form an important part of the rhetoric used in <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Russia">state-controlled media</a>, as banning on them in other countries is seen by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)">Russian foreign ministry</a> as "sacrilege" and "a perverse idea of good and evil".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEShevchenko2015&#95;363-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShevchenko2015-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The process of <a href="/wiki/Decommunization_in_Ukraine" title="Decommunization in Ukraine">decommunization in Ukraine</a>, a neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Post-Soviet_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Post-Soviet state">post-Soviet state</a>, was met with fierce criticism by Russia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEShevchenko2015&#95;363-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShevchenko2015-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/State_Anthem_of_the_Russian_Federation" class="mw-redirect" title="State Anthem of the Russian Federation">State Anthem of the Russian Federation</a>, adopted in 2000 (the same year <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> began his first term as president of Russia), uses the exact same music as the <a href="/wiki/State_Anthem_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="State Anthem of the Soviet Union">State Anthem of the Soviet Union</a>, but with new lyrics written by <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Mikhalkov" title="Sergey Mikhalkov">Sergey Mikhalkov</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Conversely, decommunization in Ukraine started during and after the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a> in 1991.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEKhotin2009&#95;368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhotin2009-368"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> With the success of the <a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_Dignity" title="Revolution of Dignity">Revolution of Dignity</a> in 2014, the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian government">Ukrainian government</a> approved <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_decommunization_laws" title="Ukrainian decommunization laws">laws</a> that outlawed <a href="/wiki/Communist_symbol" class="mw-redirect" title="Communist symbol">communist symbols</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ectniiU&#95;369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ectniiU-369"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In July 2015, President of Ukraine <a href="/wiki/Petro_Poroshenko" title="Petro Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a> signed a set of laws that started a six-month period for the removal of communist monuments (excluding <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> monuments) and renaming of public places named after communist-related themes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEShevchenko2015&#95;363-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShevchenko2015-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> At the time, this meant that 22 cities and 44 villages were set to get new names.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2016, 51,493 streets and 987 cities and villages were renamed, and 1,320 <a href="/wiki/Lenin_monuments" class="mw-redirect" title="Lenin monuments">Lenin monuments</a> and 1,069 monuments to other communist figures removed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-rdiU16&#95;373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rdiU16-373"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Violation of the law carries a penalty of a potential media ban and prison sentences of up to five years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-dwdc9415&#95;374-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dwdc9415-374"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-oscedc18515&#95;375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oscedc18515-375"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Ukraine)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of the Interior (Ukraine)">Ministry of the Interior</a> stripped the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Ukraine" title="Communist Party of Ukraine">Communist Party of Ukraine</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Ukraine_(renewed)" title="Communist Party of Ukraine (renewed)">Communist Party of Ukraine (renewed)</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Workers_and_Peasants" title="Communist Party of Workers and Peasants">Communist Party of Workers and Peasants</a> of their right to participate in elections and stated it was continuing the court actions that started in July 2014 to end the registration of <a href="/wiki/Category:Communist_parties_in_Ukraine" title="Category:Communist parties in Ukraine">communist parties in Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Banukcom24715&#95;376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Banukcom24715-376"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By 16 December 2015, these three parties had been banned in Ukraine; the Communist Party of Ukraine appealed the ban to the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Human_Rights" title="European Court of Human Rights">European Court of Human Rights</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>366<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Collapse_of_Yugoslavia_and_Balkan_conflicts">Collapse of Yugoslavia and Balkan conflicts</h3></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Nato_flyer.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Nato_flyer.jpg/250px-Nato_flyer.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="264" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Nato_flyer.jpg/477px-Nato_flyer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/98/Nato_flyer.jpg 2x" data-file-width="477" data-file-height="504" /></a><figcaption>NATO <a href="/wiki/Psyop" class="mw-redirect" title="Psyop">psyop</a> flyer during the <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo War</a> 1999.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>The Cold War had provided external stabilizing pressures. Both the United States and the Soviet Union had a vested interest in Yugoslavia's stability, ensuring it remained a buffer state in the east–west divide. This resulted in financial and political support for its regime. When the Cold War ended, this external support evaporated, leaving Yugoslavia more vulnerable to internal divisions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>369<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As Yugoslavia fragmented, <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars" title="Yugoslav Wars">the wars</a> began after <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a> declared independence in 1991. <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a>, under <a href="/wiki/Slobodan_Milo%C5%A1evi%C4%87" title="Slobodan Milošević">Slobodan Milošević</a>, opposed these moves.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_War" title="Bosnian War">The Bosnian War</a> (1992–1995) was the most brutal of the Yugoslav Wars, characterized by ethnic cleansing and genocide. International organizations, including the United Nations, struggled to manage the violence. NATO eventually intervened with airstrikes in Bosnia (1995) as part of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Deliberate_Force" title="Operation Deliberate Force">Operation Deliberate Force</a> and later in Kosovo (1999) as part of <a href="/wiki/Operation_allied_force" class="mw-redirect" title="Operation allied force">Operation Allied Force</a>. These interventions marked the transition of NATO as a deterrent to the Soviet Union, to also functioning at the time as an active peacekeeping and conflict-resolution force.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>371<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Influence">Influence</h2></div>
<p>The post-Cold War world is considered to be <a href="/wiki/Polarity_(international_relations)#Unipolarity" title="Polarity (international relations)">unipolar</a>, with the United States the sole remaining <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">superpower</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEBlum200687&#95;386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlum200687-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>373<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Cold War defined the political role of the United States after World War&#160;II—by 1989 the United States had military alliances with 50 countries, with 526,000 troops stationed abroad,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-PBS&#95;2004&#95;387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBS_2004-387"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with 326,000 in Europe (two-thirds of which were in <a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">West Germany</a>)<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEDuke1989175&#95;388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuke1989175-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and 130,000 in Asia (mainly <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-PBS&#95;2004&#95;387-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PBS_2004-387"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Cold War also marked the zenith of peacetime <a href="/wiki/Military%E2%80%93industrial_complex" title="Military–industrial complex">military–industrial complexes</a> and large-scale <a href="/wiki/History_of_military_technology" title="History of military technology">military funding of science</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002&#95;389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Enlargement_of_the_European_Union_77.gif" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union_77.gif/250px-Enlargement_of_the_European_Union_77.gif" decoding="async" width="250" height="250" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union_77.gif/500px-Enlargement_of_the_European_Union_77.gif 1.5x" data-file-width="1245" data-file-height="1245" /></a><figcaption>Since the end of the Cold War, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">EU</a> has <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">expanded eastwards</a> into the former Warsaw Pact and parts of the former Soviet Union.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Cumulative US military expenditures throughout the entire Cold War amounted to an estimated $8&#160;trillion. Nearly 100,000 Americans died in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam Wars</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTELaFeber20021&#95;390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELaFeber20021-390"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>377<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Although Soviet casualties are difficult to estimate, as a share of gross national product the financial cost for the Soviet Union was much higher than that incurred by the United States.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGaddis2005213&#95;391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaddis2005213-391"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Millions died in the superpowers' <a href="/wiki/Proxy_war" title="Proxy war">proxy wars</a> around the globe, most notably in eastern Asia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEGaddis2005266&#95;392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaddis2005266-392"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>N<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Most of the proxy wars and subsidies for local conflicts ended along with the Cold War; interstate wars, ethnic wars, revolutionary wars, as well as refugee and displaced persons crises have declined sharply in the post-Cold War years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEMarshallGurr2006&#95;394-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarshallGurr2006-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>380<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The aftermath of the Cold War is, however, not considered to be concluded. Many of the economic and social tensions that were exploited to fuel Cold War competition in parts of the Third World remain acute. The breakdown of state control in a number of areas formerly ruled by communist governments produced new civil and ethnic conflicts, particularly in the former <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia" title="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>. In Central and Eastern Europe, the end of the Cold War has ushered in an era of <a href="/wiki/Economic_growth" title="Economic growth">economic growth</a> and an increase in the number of <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracy" title="Liberal democracy">liberal democracies</a>, while in other parts of the world, such as Afghanistan, independence was accompanied by <a href="/wiki/Failed_state" title="Failed state">state failure</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEHalliday20012e&#95;264-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalliday20012e-264"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has been posited by several scholars that the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a> and the end of <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communism</a> as a global force in the post-Cold War era allowed <a href="/wiki/Neoliberal" class="mw-redirect" title="Neoliberal">neoliberal</a> <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalism</a> to become the dominant global system, which has resulted in rising <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">economic inequality</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="In_popular_culture">In popular culture</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Culture_during_the_Cold_War" title="Culture during the Cold War">Culture during the Cold War</a></div>
<p>The Cold War endures as a popular topic reflected in entertainment media, and continuing to the present with Cold War-themed feature films, novels, television and web series, and other media.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Historiography">Historiography</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Historiography_of_the_Cold_War" title="Historiography of the Cold War">Historiography of the Cold War</a></div>
<p>Interpreting the course and origins of the conflict has been a source of heated controversy among historians, political scientists, and journalists.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTENashel1999&#95;399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENashel1999-399"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In particular, historians have sharply disagreed as to who was responsible for the breakdown of Soviet–US relations after the Second World War; and whether the conflict between the two superpowers was inevitable or could have been avoided.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEAmbroseBrinkley2011789–799&#95;400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAmbroseBrinkley2011789–799-400"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>386<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Historians have also disagreed on what exactly the Cold War was, what the sources of the conflict were, and how to disentangle patterns of action and reaction between the two sides.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEHalliday20012e&#95;264-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalliday20012e-264"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Although explanations of the origins of the conflict in academic discussions are complex and diverse, several general schools of thought on the subject can be identified. Historians commonly speak of three different approaches to the study of the Cold War: "orthodox" accounts, "revisionism", and "post-revisionism".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002&#95;389-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>"Orthodox" accounts place responsibility for the Cold War on the Soviet Union and its expansion further into Europe.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002&#95;389-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> "Revisionist" writers place more responsibility for the breakdown of post-war peace on the United States, citing a range of US efforts to isolate and confront the Soviet Union well before the end of World War II.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002&#95;389-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> "Post-revisionists" see the events of the Cold War as more nuanced and attempt to be more balanced in determining what occurred during the Cold War.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002&#95;389-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalhoun2002-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Much of the historiography on the Cold War weaves together two or even all three of these broad categories.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-FOOTNOTEByrd2003&#95;84-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEByrd2003-84"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>

<li id="cite&#95;note-duration-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-duration_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-duration_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFService2015">Service 2015</a>, p.&#160;<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. </li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFJowettO&#39;Donnell2005">Jowett &amp; O'Donnell 2005</a>, pp.&#160;21–23: "In fact, the word disinformation is a cognate for the Russian dezinformatsia, taken from the name of a division of the KGB devoted to black propaganda."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-103"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-103">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMatray2002">Matray 2002</a>: "South Korea's President Rhee was obsessed with accomplishing early reunification through military means. The Truman administration's fear that Rhee would launch an invasion prompted it to limit South Korea's military capabilities, refusing to provide tanks, heavy artillery, and combat planes. This did not stop the South Koreans from initiating most of the border clashes with North Korean forces at the thirty-eighth parallel beginning in the summer of 1948 and reaching a high level of intensity and violence a year later. Historians now acknowledge that the two Koreas already were waging a civil conflict when North Korea's attack opened the conventional phase of the war."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-106"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-106">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMatray2002">Matray 2002</a>: "Contradicting traditional assumptions, however, available declassified Soviet documents demonstrate that throughout 1949 Stalin consistently refused to approve Kim Il Sung's persistent requests to approve an invasion of South Korea. The Soviet leader believed that North Korea had not achieved either military superiority north of the parallel or political strength south of that line. His main concern was the threat South Korea posed to North Korea's survival, for example fearing an invasion northward following U.S. military withdrawal in June 1949."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-124">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071117094223/http://files.osa.ceu.hu/holdings/selection/rip/4/av/1956-44.html">"Revolt in Hungary"</a>. </li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-161"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-161">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">34,374,483 square kilometres (13,272,062&#160;sq&#160;mi).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-189"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-189">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPradosJimenez-Bacardi2019">Prados &amp; Jimenez-Bacardi 2019</a>: "The memorandum showed no concern for international law or the unspoken nature of these operations as terrorist attacks."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-190"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-190">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation report cs1">International Policy Report (Report). <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>: <a href="/wiki/Center_for_International_Policy" title="Center for International Policy">Center for International Policy</a>. 1977. pp.&#160;<span class="nowrap">10–</span>12. <q>To coordinate and carry out its war of terror and destruction during the early 1960s, the CIA established a base of operations, known as <a href="/wiki/JMWAVE" title="JMWAVE">JMWAVE</a>.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=report&amp;rft.btitle=International+Policy+Report&amp;rft.place=Washington%2C+D.C.&amp;rft.pages=10-12&amp;rft.pub=Center+for+International+Policy&amp;rft.date=1977&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACold+War" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-206"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-206">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">National Research Council Committee on Antarctic Policy and Science, p. 33</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-276"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-276">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFColl2004">Coll 2004</a>, pp.&#160;47–49: "Frustrated and hoping to discredit him, the KGB initially planted false stories that Amin was a CIA agent. In the autumn these rumors rebounded on the KGB in a strange case of "<a href="/wiki/Blowback_(intelligence)" title="Blowback (intelligence)">blowback</a>," the term used by spies to describe planted propaganda that filters back to confuse the country that first set the story loose."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-277"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-277">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFJones,_S.2010">Jones, S. 2010</a>, pp.&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/ingraveyardofemp00jone_0/page/16">16</a>–17: "'It was total nonsense,' said the CIA's <a href="/wiki/Graham_E._Fuller" title="Graham E. Fuller">Graham Fuller</a>. 'I would have been thrilled to have those kinds of contacts with Amin, but they didn't exist.'"</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-312"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-312">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/international/contents.html">Official Energy Statistics of the US Government</a>", EIA&#160;– International Energy Data and Analysis. Retrieved on 4 July 2008.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-393"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-393">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKim2014">Kim 2014</a>, p.&#160;45: "With three of the four major Cold War fault lines—divided Germany, divided Korea, divided China, and divided Vietnam—East Asia acquired the dubious distinction of having engendered the largest number of armed conflicts resulting in higher fatalities between 1945 and 1994 than any other region or sub-region. Even in Asia, while Central and South Asia produced a regional total of 2.8 million in human fatalities, East Asia's regional total is 10.4 million including the Chinese Civil War (1 million), the Korean War (3 million), the Vietnam War (2 million), and the Pol Pot genocide in Cambodia (1 to 2 million)."</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

(August 2024)">page&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>.</span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-230"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-230">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200813004557/https://www.dtra.mil/Portals/61/Documents/NTPR/2-Hist_Rpt_Atm/1962_DNA_6040F.pdf">"OPERATION DOMINIC 1962"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. </li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-385"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-385">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/country_profiles/1217752.stm">"Country profile: United States of America"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/BBC_News" title="BBC News">BBC News</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-395"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-395">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFGhodsee2018" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Kristen_Ghodsee" title="Kristen Ghodsee">Ghodsee, Kristen</a> (2018). <i><a href="/wiki/Why_Women_Have_Better_Sex_Under_Socialism" title="Why Women Have Better Sex Under Socialism">Why Women Have Better Sex Under Socialism</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Vintage_Books" title="Vintage Books">Vintage Books</a>. pp.&#160;<span class="nowrap">3–</span>4. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1568588902" title="Special:BookSources/978-1568588902"><bdi>978-1568588902</bdi></a>. <q>Without the looming threat of a rival superpower, the last thirty years of global neoliberalism have witnessed a rapid shriveling of social programs that protect citizens from cyclical instability and financial crises and reduce the vast inequality of economic outcomes between those at the top and bottom of the income distribution.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Why+Women+Have+Better+Sex+Under+Socialism&amp;rft.pages=3-4&amp;rft.pub=Vintage+Books&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.isbn=978-1568588902&amp;rft.aulast=Ghodsee&amp;rft.aufirst=Kristen&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACold+War" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-396"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-396">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFGreene2020" class="citation journal cs1"><a href="/wiki/Julie_Greene_(historian)" title="Julie Greene (historian)">Greene, Julie</a> (April 2020). "Bookends to a Gentler Capitalism: Complicating the Notion of First and Second Gilded Ages". <i><a href="/wiki/The_Journal_of_the_Gilded_Age_and_Progressive_Era" title="The Journal of the Gilded Age and Progressive Era">The Journal of the Gilded Age and Progressive Era</a></i>. <b>19</b> (2). <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>: <span class="nowrap">197–</span>205. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FS1537781419000628">10.1017/S1537781419000628</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Journal+of+the+Gilded+Age+and+Progressive+Era&amp;rft.atitle=Bookends+to+a+Gentler+Capitalism%3A+Complicating+the+Notion+of+First+and+Second+Gilded+Ages&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=197-205&amp;rft.date=2020-04&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FS1537781419000628&amp;rft.aulast=Greene&amp;rft.aufirst=Julie&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACold+War" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-397"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-397">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFBartel2022" class="citation book cs1">Bartel, Fritz (2022). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674976788"><i>The Triumph of Broken Promises: The End of the Cold War and the Rise of Neoliberalism</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University_Press" title="Harvard University Press">Harvard University Press</a>. pp.&#160;<span class="nowrap">5–</span>6. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780674976788" title="Special:BookSources/9780674976788"><bdi>9780674976788</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Triumph+of+Broken+Promises%3A+The+End+of+the+Cold+War+and+the+Rise+of+Neoliberalism&amp;rft.pages=5-6&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2022&amp;rft.isbn=9780674976788&amp;rft.aulast=Bartel&amp;rft.aufirst=Fritz&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hup.harvard.edu%2Fcatalog.php%3Fisbn%3D9780674976788&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACold+War" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-398"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-398">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFGerstle2022" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Gary_Gerstle" title="Gary Gerstle">Gerstle, Gary</a> (2022). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://global.oup.com/academic/product/the-rise-and-fall-of-the-neoliberal-order-9780197519646?cc=us&amp;lang=en&amp;"><i>The Rise and Fall of the Neoliberal Order: America and the World in the Free Market Era</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. pp.&#160;<span class="nowrap">10–</span>12, 149. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-751964-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-751964-6"><bdi>978-0-19-751964-6</bdi></a>. <q>The collapse of communism, then, opened the entire world to capitalist penetration, shrank the imaginative and ideological space in which opposition to capitalist thought and practices might incubate, and impelled those who remained leftists to redefine their radicalism in alternative terms, which turned out to be those that capitalist systems could more, rather than less, easily manage. This was the moment when neoliberalism in the United States went from being a political movement to a political order.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Rise+and+Fall+of+the+Neoliberal+Order%3A+America+and+the+World+in+the+Free+Market+Era&amp;rft.pages=10-12%2C+149&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2022&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-751964-6&amp;rft.aulast=Gerstle&amp;rft.aufirst=Gary&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fglobal.oup.com%2Facademic%2Fproduct%2Fthe-rise-and-fall-of-the-neoliberal-order-9780197519646%3Fcc%3Dus%26lang%3Den%26&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACold+War" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-FOOTNOTENashel1999-399"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTENashel1999_399-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFNashel1999">Nashel 1999</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-FOOTNOTEAmbroseBrinkley2011789–799-400"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAmbroseBrinkley2011789–799_400-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFAmbroseBrinkley2011">Ambrose &amp; Brinkley 2011</a>, pp.&#160;789–799.</span>
</li>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Journal_articles">Journal articles</h3></div>

<ul><li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFAftergood2017" class="citation journal cs1">Aftergood, S. (2017). <li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMilestones:&#95;1969–1976" class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://history.state.gov/milestones/1969-1976/detente">"Milestones: 1969–1976 – Office of the Historian"</a>. <i>history.state.gov</i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190611223144/https://history.state.gov/milestones/1969-1976/detente">Archived</a> from the original on 11 June 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 June</span> 2019</span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=history.state.gov&amp;rft.atitle=Milestones%3A+1969%E2%80%931976+%E2%80%93+Office+of+the+Historian&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fhistory.state.gov%2Fmilestones%2F1969-1976%2Fdetente&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACold+War" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFHolodkov1956" class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB76/doc8.pdf">"Report by Soviet Deputy Interior Minister M.N. Holodkov to Interior Minister N. P. Dudorov (15 November 1956)"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>The 1956 Hungarian Revolution, A History in Documents</i>. George Washington University: The National Security Archive. 4 November 2002. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060908023144/http://www.gwu.edu/%7Ensarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB76/doc8.pdf">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 8 September 2006<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 September</span> 2006</span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+1956+Hungarian+Revolution%2C+A+History+in+Documents&amp;rft.atitle=Report+by+Soviet+Deputy+Interior+Minister+M.N.+Holodkov+to+Interior+Minister+N.+P.+Dudorov+%2815+November+1956%29&amp;rft.date=2002-11-04&amp;rft&#95;id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gwu.edu%2F~nsarchiv%2FNSAEBB%2FNSAEBB76%2Fdoc8.pdf&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACold+War" class="Z3988"></span></li>
<li><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFWorld&#95;Peace&#95;Foundation2015" class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://sites.tufts.edu/atrocityendings/2015/08/07/cambodia-u-s-bombing-civil-war-khmer-rouge/">"Cambodia: U.S. bombing, civil war, &amp; Khmer Rouge"</a>. <a href="/wiki/World_Peace_Foundation" title="World Peace Foundation">World Peace Foundation</a>. 7 August 2015. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190714181839/https://sites.tufts.edu/atrocityendings/2015/08/07/cambodia-u-s-bombing-civil-war-khmer-rouge/">Archived</a> from the original on 14 July 2019<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 August</span> 2019</span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Cambodia%3A+U.S.+bombing%2C+civil+war%2C+%26+Khmer+Rouge&amp;rft.pub=World+Peace+Foundation&amp;rft.date=2015-08-07&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fsites.tufts.edu%2Fatrocityendings%2F2015%2F08%2F07%2Fcambodia-u-s-bombing-civil-war-khmer-rouge%2F&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACold+War" class="Z3988"></span></li></ul>

<ul><li><b><span class="nowrap"><span class="mw-image-border noviewer" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="16" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg/60px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg/120px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></span></span> </span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Soviet_Union" title="Portal:Soviet Union">Soviet Union&#32;portal</a></b></li>
<li><span class="noviewer" typeof="mw:File"><span title="Category"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/20px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="16" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/40px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="180" data-file-height="185" /></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Category:Soviet_Union" title="Category:Soviet Union">Category</a></li></ul>
